sections.introTitle: Proving Marketing's Value: A B2B SaaS Reality Check
sections.introDescription: A Practical Guide for CMOs in the Trenches. This guide provides actionable frameworks and proven strategies to help you demonstrate marketing's true contribution to revenue in today's complex B2B environment. Instead of theoretical models, you'll find battle-tested approaches that address both the technical and organizational challenges of attribution.

realProblemCallout.title: The Real Problem
realProblemCallout.content: Your marketing team is in a tough spot. Sales takes credit for every win. Leadership questions your spend. Your fancy dashboards aren't convincing anyone. Let's fix this mess.

items.title: Surface issue
items.description: No clear attribution model exists

items.title: Real problem
items.description: Deep organizational mistrust between teams

items.title: Practical example
items.description: Sales says "that $30K event was useless" while Marketing says "three deals came from it" - and neither has proof

items.title: Current reality
items.description: Only 40% of deals have any marketing touchpoints properly recorded

items.title: Political blindness
items.description: Most attribution projects crash and burn because they ignore entrenched political interests

items.title: Data quality assumptions
items.description: They assume clean, complete CRM data (it never is)

items.title: Overcomplexity
items.description: They push complex models before basics work

items.title: Lack of enforcement
items.description: They lack executive enforcement to make teams comply

items.title: Human element
items.description: They fail to acknowledge the messy human elements

sections.phase1Description: Focus on basics, quick wins, and relationship repair

steps.title: Data Cleanup & Baseline
steps.description: Establish your current state and document the gaps

steps.title: Focus on Go-Forward Data
steps.description: Fix the future rather than the past

steps.title: Quick Win
steps.description: Demonstrate value with a focused example

items.title: Audit recent deals
items.description: Audit last 6-12 months of closed-won deals

items.title: Manual tracing
items.description: Manually trace 20 major deals with sales and marketing together

items.title: Document customer journey
items.description: Document the real customer journey, including offline touchpoints

items.title: Quantify the gap
items.description: Quantify the current gap: "Marketing touches missing from 60% of deals"

goForwardDataSteps.title: Fix the Future, Not the Past

items.title: Set a clear cutoff date
items.description: "From today, all new leads must have these 5 fields completed"

items.title: Create simple checklist
items.description: Create a simple checklist for sales to follow on new opportunities

items.title: Apply new tracking
items.description: Apply new tracking to fresh pipeline, not historical deals

items.title: Prioritize cleanup
items.description: Only clean historical data for your top 50 accounts or active opportunities

items.title: Executive communication
items.description: Tell your CEO: "We're fixing the future, not rewriting the past"

items.title: Pipeline council
items.description: Weekly marketing-sales "pipeline council" with mandatory attendance

items.title: Rotate leadership
items.description: Rotate meeting leadership between Sales VP and CMO

items.title: Cross-team participation
items.description: Invite three salespeople to join marketing planning meetings

items.title: Join sales calls
items.description: Have three marketers join sales calls regularly

items.title: Shared reality
items.description: End the finger-pointing with a "shared reality" document all sides sign

items.title: Keep it simple
items.description: Start simple: First-touch + last-touch attribution only

items.title: Fix UTM discipline
items.description: Fix UTM parameter discipline with automated checking

items.title: Clean lead sources
items.description: Clean up lead source field in CRM (limit to 10 sources maximum)

items.title: Create mandatory fields
items.description: Create mandatory fields for sales to acknowledge marketing contribution

items.title: Choose your strongest channel
items.description: Pick your strongest channel (likely webinars or content)

items.title: Trace full impact
items.description: Trace its full impact on 10 recent deals with sales team present

items.title: Create mini case study
items.description: Create a mini case study showing true ROI just for this channel

items.title: Present with sales
items.description: Present it to your CEO with sales leadership in the room

webinarExample.title: Concrete Example: Webinar Attribution
webinarExample.content: Let's say you run monthly industry webinars. Track this specific example: Webinar: "2025 Industry Trends" (March 15) | Attendance: 250 prospects | MQLs generated: 80 | Sales meetings set: 30 | Opportunities created: 12 | Deals closed: 4 | Total revenue: $200,000 | Total cost: $15,000 | ROI: 13.3x | Present this with a timeline showing how leads moved through stages. Include sales team members who closed these deals to validate the story. This tangible example makes attribution real.

sections.phase2Description: Expand what works and formalize the process

enhancedAttributionSteps.title: Taking Attribution to the Next Level

items.title: U-shaped attribution
items.description: Move to U-shaped attribution (first touch, lead conversion, and close)

items.title: Track offline interactions
items.description: Start tracking offline interactions (events, calls) in your CRM

items.title: Lead handoff SLA
items.description: Create a proper lead handoff SLA with teeth

items.title: Marketing responsibility
items.description: Marketing: Ensures lead quality meets agreed criteria

items.title: Sales responsibility
items.description: Sales: Must follow up within 48 hours or lead gets reassigned

items.title: Joint accountability
items.description: Both: Joint accountability for conversion metrics

sections.revenueFocusTitle: Stay Focused on Revenue, Not Vanity Metrics

items.title: Hard rule
items.description: Every marketing metric must connect to pipeline or revenue

items.title: Dashboard discipline
items.description: For every "activity" metric, show the conversion outcome

items.title: Example
items.description: Instead of "1,000 webinar attendees," report "1,000 attendees → 200 MQLs → 50 opportunities"

items.title: Ruthless prioritization
items.description: If a marketing channel shows lots of activity but minimal pipeline impact for two consecutive quarters, reallocate budget regardless of how "engaging" it seems

items.title: Executive communication
items.description: Always lead with pipeline and revenue impact, never with vanity engagement numbers

items.title: Merge operations teams
items.description: Merge sales ops, marketing ops, and customer success ops teams

items.title: Dedicated leadership
items.description: Appoint a dedicated RevOps leader reporting to COO (or both CRO/CMO)

items.title: Transition plan
items.description: Create 90-day transition plan with clear role definitions

items.title: Shared dashboard
items.description: Shared dashboard everyone trusts

items.title: Weekly review
items.description: Weekly data review to catch and fix attribution issues

items.title: CEO/CFO dashboard
items.description: Create an executive dashboard showing key metrics

items.title: Marketing-sourced pipeline
items.description: Marketing-sourced pipeline (direct creation)

items.title: Marketing-influenced pipeline
items.description: Marketing-influenced pipeline (nurtured by marketing)

items.title: Pipeline-to-spend ratio
items.description: Pipeline-to-spend ratio by channel

items.title: Time lag visualization
items.description: Time lag between marketing activity and pipeline impact

items.title: Joint presentation
items.description: Monthly executive review with both CRO and CMO presenting together

items.title: Create a 1-page guide
items.description: Create a 1-page "Attribution 101" guide for executives that defines basic terms, shows visual examples, explains correlation vs. causation, and clarifies why perfect attribution is impossible but directional data is valuable

items.title: Tailor reporting by role
items.description: CEO: Focus on pipeline growth, marketing ROI, and strategic impact | CFO: Emphasize unit economics, payback period, and expense justification | Board: Show competitive advantage and market position improvements

items.title: Pre-empt common objections
items.description: "How do we know it wasn't just Sales effort?" (Show controlled tests) | "Why isn't attribution perfect?" (Explain B2B complexity vs. B2C) | "Why does marketing need this much budget?" (Demonstrate pipeline ratio)

items.title: Monthly reconciliation
items.description: Monthly finance-marketing reconciliation meeting

items.title: Clear CAC definition
items.description: Clear definition of what's included in CAC calculations

items.title: Cost allocation agreement
items.description: Agreement on how to allocate staff costs, brand vs. demand generation spend, content production costs, and overhead allocation

items.title: Documented methodology
items.description: Documented methodology signed off by CFO

items.title: Consistent tracking
items.description: Consistent spend tracking that matches financial systems

items.title: Example clarification
items.description: "The ROI on our website redesign will be calculated over 24 months since that's its expected lifetime"

items.title: Sales compensation link
items.description: 10% of sales compensation tied to marketing-influenced deals

items.title: Marketing compensation link
items.description: 20% of marketing compensation tied to revenue outcomes

items.title: Recognition program
items.description: Quarterly recognition for sales-marketing collaboration

items.title: Public leaderboard
items.description: Public leaderboard tracking lead follow-up compliance

items.title: Enforcement protocol
items.description: Strict enforcement protocol: Repeated non-compliance escalated directly to CRO/CEO

items.title: Executive sign-off
items.description: Have your CEO formally approve a one-page policy that states: 1. All leads must be followed up within 48 hours | 2. All opportunities must have source tracking | 3. Exceptions require VP-level written approval | 4. Repeated violations impact variable compensation | 5. No exceptions for top performers – they set the example

items.title: W-shaped model
items.description: Move to W-shaped model (first touch, MQL, opportunity creation)

items.title: Content influence tracking
items.description: Implement content influence tracking

items.title: Account-based measurement
items.description: Account-based marketing measurement

items.title: Multi-stakeholder tracking
items.description: Multi-stakeholder deal tracking

items.title: Deal velocity impact
items.description: Impact of marketing on deal velocity and size

items.title: Account engagement score
items.description: Track depth and breadth of engagement | Depth: How many interactions per key contact | Breadth: What percentage of buying committee is engaged | Quality: Types of content consumed (thought leadership vs product)

items.title: ABM attribution metrics
items.description: Buying committee coverage (e.g., "Marketing engaged 8/10 key stakeholders") | Account progression through journey stages | Time-to-first-meeting reduction | Target account pipeline growth | Win rate improvements in ABM accounts vs non-ABM

items.title: Sales and marketing orchestration
items.description: Track coordinated touchpoints across teams | Measure sales follow-up on marketing-enabled accounts | Compare results: "ABM accounts close 40% faster with 2.5x larger deal size"

items.title: Operational implementation
items.description: Create custom fields in CRM to tag each contact by role (technical buyer, economic buyer, etc.) | Set up account scoring rules in your marketing automation platform | Example: "Technical buyer opens email = 1 point, C-suite attends webinar = 5 points" | Build account coverage report showing percentage of key roles engaged | Use color-coding in CRM: Red = <25% coverage, Yellow = 50% coverage, Green = 75%+ coverage

items.title: Track each stakeholder separately
items.description: Technical evaluator (influenced by webinars, documentation) | Business decision-maker (influenced by ROI calculators, case studies) | Executive sponsor (influenced by thought leadership, peer events)

items.title: Unify at account level
items.description: Combine all contact activity into account-level view | Weight influence based on stakeholder role | Show "marketing coverage" across buying committee | Example: "Marketing influenced 3/4 key decision-makers at Acme Corp"

items.title: Allocate credit across channels
items.description: When one account engages with multiple marketing channels, assign partial credit to each | Technical buyer downloads whitepaper (25% credit) | Business buyer attends webinar (25% credit) | Executive attends industry dinner (50% credit) | All three views connected at the account level in CRM | Report shows: "3 channels influenced this $250K deal with 75% buying committee coverage"

items.title: Handle repeat channel engagement
items.description: Set diminishing returns for repeated touches in the same channel | First webinar attendance: 10 points | Second webinar: 5 additional points | Third+ webinar: 2 additional points each | Cap any single channel at 40% of total attribution | This prevents artificially inflating one channel's impact | Example: "Three webinar attendances count as 17 points total, not 30 points"

items.title: Channel mix optimization
items.description: Channel mix optimization based on historical performance

items.title: Pipeline forecasting
items.description: Pipeline forecasting from marketing activities

items.title: Early warning system
items.description: Early warning system for pipeline gaps

items.title: Account prioritization
items.description: Account prioritization for marketing support

items.title: Prerequisites for algorithmic attribution
items.description: Data quality consistently above 90% completion rate | At least 6-8 months of reliable attribution history | Enough deal volume for statistical significance (50+ per quarter) | Clear patterns emerging from simpler attribution models | Technical resources to implement and maintain complex models

items.title: When to use third-party AI tools
items.description: Your deal complexity exceeds what manual models can handle | You have 100+ touches across multiple channels per deal | You need to factor in thousands of variables simultaneously | Your buying cycles span 12+ months with multiple decision-makers

items.title: Start small with advanced analytics
items.description: Begin with a single high-value segment or product line | Run algorithmic and traditional attribution in parallel for 3 months | Compare results and validate against known deals | Only expand when the advanced model proves more accurate

items.title: Warning
items.description: Fancy AI attribution that lacks good base data will produce misleading results. Fix your data fundamentals first.

values: Share of voice in industry publications

sections.brandPipelineConnection: Link to pipeline: Track these correlations monthly: Branded search → Pipeline: When branded search volume increased 30%, marketing-sourced pipeline grew 22% in the following 6 weeks | Direct traffic → Conversion: Direct visitors convert to leads at 4.2x the rate of paid traffic | Sales cycle impact: Prospects who engaged with 3+ brand content pieces closed 35% faster | Win rate connection: Deal win rates are 15% higher when prospects attended a thought leadership webinar | Implementation tip: Create a simple time-lag analysis showing branded search trends overlaid with pipeline creation (offset by your typical sales cycle).
sections.salesObstacleTitle: Obstacle: Sales Won't Enter Data Properly

items.title: Reality
items.description: Salespeople hate administrative work and won't consistently track leads

items.title: Make it simple
items.description: Make it dead simple (one-click options in CRM)

items.title: Build it into process
items.description: Build it into their process (can't advance opportunity without it)

items.title: Tie to compensation
items.description: Tie it to their compensation (incomplete data = incomplete commission)

items.title: Provide support
items.description: Provide a sales operations person to do it for top performers

sections.crmObstacleTitle: Obstacle: Your CRM is a Mess

items.title: Reality
items.description: Years of bad hygiene, custom fields, and workarounds

items.title: Focus cleanup
items.description: Don't boil the ocean - clean only what you need

items.title: Consider separate database
items.description: Use a separate marketing database if needed

items.title: Use middleware
items.description: Consider middleware tools that sit between systems

items.title: Prioritize new data
items.description: Focus on go-forward data first, then backfill

items.title: Reality
items.description: Many key touchpoints happen offline or get missed

items.title: Phase 1 (30 days)
items.description: Get 50% of phone calls logged in CRM | Provide call scripts with fill-in-the-blank CRM templates | Have sales ops audit call logs weekly and flag gaps | Make it public: "Team A logged 85% of calls, Team B only 40%"

items.title: Phase 2 (90 days)
items.description: Reach 75% tracking compliance | Implement click-to-call in CRM to auto-log calls | Set up calendar sync to capture meetings automatically | Create 5-second mobile form for logging impromptu conversations

items.title: Phase 3 (6 months)
items.description: Achieve 90%+ visibility | Connect digital and offline touchpoints into one timeline | Use AI tools to transcribe and auto-categorize calls | Implement QR codes at in-person events to track engagement

items.title: Reality
items.description: Your CEO wants perfect attribution by next quarter

items.title: Show phased plan
items.description: Show the 30/60/90 day plan with specific deliverables

items.title: Deliver MVP quickly
items.description: Deliver a working "minimum viable attribution" model fast

items.title: Find early success
items.description: Find one early success story and amplify it

items.title: Get influential support
items.description: Get an influential board member or advisor to back your approach

sections.salesCycleObstacleTitle: Obstacle: Long Sales Cycles Complicate Attribution

items.title: Reality
items.description: Your 9-18 month sales cycle crosses multiple campaigns and teams

items.title: Milestone credit
items.description: Create milestone credit: first touch, MQL, meeting set, opportunity

items.title: Track velocity metrics
items.description: Track velocity metrics (time between stages) influenced by marketing

items.title: Rolling attribution
items.description: Implement rolling attribution windows (12-month lookback)

items.title: Leading indicators
items.description: Use "influenced pipeline" as a leading indicator while waiting for revenue

sections.servicesObstacleTitle: Obstacle: Services Business Has Different Patterns

items.title: Reality
items.description: Professional services are sold differently than SaaS products

items.title: Separate models
items.description: Create separate attribution models for product vs. services

items.title: Track influence metrics
items.description: Track influence metrics for services (referrals, case studies)

items.title: Relationship-based attribution
items.description: Implement relationship-based attribution for key accounts

items.title: Measure expansion impact
items.description: Measure marketing's impact on services expansion and upsell

values: "20% of services scopes cited our industry report"
"Financial services case study influenced 8 new SOWs"

sections.dashboardDescription: Keep it simple. One page everyone trusts.

items.title: Weekly publishing
items.description: Published every Monday morning by RevOps

items.title: Company-wide sharing
items.description: Shared in company-wide Slack channel

items.title: Weekly review
items.description: Reviewed in weekly sales-marketing alignment meeting

items.title: Executive distribution
items.description: Sent to CEO/CRO/CMO via email

items.title: Visual display
items.description: Displayed on monitors in sales and marketing areas

items.title: Executive review
items.description: Included in monthly executive business review

items.title: Trend tracking
items.description: Tracked over time with 13-week rolling chart

items.title: Start meetings with metrics
items.description: Start each team meeting by reviewing these numbers

items.title: Public celebration
items.description: Celebrate improvements publicly

items.title: Immediate action
items.description: Address declining metrics immediately

items.title: Accountability
items.description: Hold teams accountable for their owned metrics

items.title: Success stories
items.description: Share weekly "win stories" that reinforce the metrics

attributionModelTable.title: Begin with this simple model, then evolve

items.title: Marketing-Sourced Pipeline
items.description: Definition: Net new opportunities that originated directly from a marketing activity | Example: Prospect filled out demo request form from paid ad | Measurement: First-touch attribution comes from marketing channel | Typical target: 25-40% of total pipeline

items.title: Marketing-Influenced Pipeline
items.description: Definition: Opportunities that had meaningful marketing engagement during the sales process | Example: Prospect attended webinar after initial sales contact | Measurement: Any opportunity with 2+ marketing touches | Typical target: 60-80% of total pipeline

items.title: Marketing-Influenced Customer Expansion
items.description: Definition: Upsells or cross-sells facilitated by marketing activities to existing customers | Example: Current customer purchased additional product after joining user group | Measurement: Expansion revenue with marketing touchpoints in prior 90 days | Typical target: 30-50% of expansion revenue

workshopSteps.title: Run this 2-hour session with sales and marketing leadership

steps.title: Step 2: Map closed deals
steps.description: Have each team map 3 recently closed deals

steps.title: Step 3: Document touchpoints
steps.description: Identify every touchpoint in the customer journey

steps.title: Step 4: Present findings
steps.description: Present findings to the whole group

steps.title: Step 5: Identify gaps
steps.description: Document gaps between perception and reality

steps.title: Step 6: Create action items
steps.description: Create action items to fix tracking issues

steps.title: Step 7: Agree on success
steps.description: Agree on a shared definition of success

sections.pipelineCouncilTitle: Weekly Pipeline Council: Structure and Escalation

items.title: Meeting setup
items.description: 45 minutes, every Monday morning | Required attendees: Sales leaders, Marketing leaders, RevOps | Standing agenda: 1. Review dashboard metrics (5 min) | 2. Celebrate wins and collaborations (5 min) | 3. Pipeline deep-dive on 2-3 key accounts (15 min) | 4. Address process breakdowns (15 min) | 5. Next steps and owners (5 min)

items.title: Escalation matrix
items.description: Level 1: Resolve in pipeline council meeting (same day) | Level 2: Escalate to CRO/CMO (within 48 hours) | Level 3: CEO makes final call (within 72 hours)

items.title: Documentation
items.description: Document decisions in a shared "source of truth" that all teams can reference when questions arise

items.title: Continuous improvement
items.description: End each pipeline meeting with: "What did we learn this week?" | Capture insights about what's working and what's not | Identify one channel or tactic to optimize next week | Make concrete changes to campaigns based on pipeline data | Example: "We noticed technical buyers engage more with how-to content vs. ROI tools. Let's adjust our mix next week." | Assign specific owners to implement the change | Report results at the next meeting

sections.organizationTitle: Making This Work In Your Organization

items.title: Pipeline impact
items.description: "Marketing will directly source 30% of pipeline within 6 months"

items.title: Cost efficiency
items.description: "We'll reduce customer acquisition cost by 15% through better channel mix"

items.title: Investment clarity
items.description: "You'll see which marketing investments drive revenue, not just leads"

items.title: Lead quality
items.description: "You'll get better quality leads that close faster"

items.title: Account insights
items.description: "We'll provide insights on which accounts need marketing support"

items.title: Revenue-focused campaigns
items.description: "Marketing will focus on campaigns that actually help you close deals"

items.title: Time efficiency
items.description: "We'll stop wasting your time with poor-fit prospects"

items.title: Credit for impact
items.description: "Your work will get proper credit in the revenue process"

items.title: Data-driven investment
items.description: "We'll invest more in channels that show clear ROI"

items.title: Budget defense
items.description: "You'll have data to defend budgets and programs"

items.title: Sales partnership
items.description: "Sales will become allies, not adversaries"

items.title: Customer adoption
items.description: "You'll see which marketing-sourced customers adopt features faster"

items.title: Content-onboarding connection
items.description: "We'll track which content types lead to better onboarding completion"

items.title: Aligned marketing
items.description: "Marketing will align content with product adoption milestones"

items.title: Pre-sale to post-sale correlation
items.description: "We'll identify correlation between pre-sale content engagement and post-sale feature usage"

items.title: Expansion revenue
items.description: "Expansion revenue will be tied back to adoption marketing activities"

sections.measuringSuccessDescription: Don't wait for perfect attribution to prove marketing works. Track these indicators at 30/60/90 days:

items.title: Meeting attendance
items.description: Sales-marketing weekly meeting attendance at 90%+

items.title: Lead source completion
items.description: Lead source field completed for 80%+ of new opportunities

items.title: UTM standardization
items.description: UTM parameters standardized across all digital channels

items.title: Baseline established
items.description: Baseline metrics established for last 6 months

items.title: First model implemented
items.description: First attribution model implemented (simple version)

items.title: Executive dashboard
items.description: Executive dashboard launched with 3-5 key metrics

items.title: Lead follow-up improvement
items.description: Lead follow-up time reduced by 30%

items.title: Sales acknowledgment
items.description: Marketing contribution to pipeline acknowledged by sales leadership

items.title: Pipeline tracking
items.description: Marketing-sourced pipeline percentage established and tracked

items.title: Channel ROI
items.description: Channel-level ROI available for top 3 marketing channels

items.title: Executive adoption
items.description: CXO team using marketing data in business reviews

items.title: Sales requests
items.description: Sales requesting marketing support for specific accounts/opportunities

items.title: Complete attribution
items.description: Complete U-shaped attribution model functioning

items.title: Visible influence
items.description: Marketing influence visible on 80%+ of deals

items.title: Budget reallocation
items.description: Budget allocation shifting based on ROI data

items.title: Joint planning
items.description: Sales and marketing planning campaigns together

items.title: Set quarterly review cycles
items.description: Reassess attribution rules every 3 months | Update channel definitions as new tactics emerge | Refine lead scoring based on conversion data

items.title: Adapt to business changes
items.description: New product lines may need different attribution weights | Market shifts might change buyer journey timing | Sales team restructuring requires process updates

items.title: Incorporate learnings
items.description: If webinars consistently influence late-stage deals, increase their weight | If certain content types predict higher win rates, prioritize them | If sales cycles compress in certain segments, adjust time decay models

items.title: Monitor market changes
items.description: Flag major competitor moves that could invalidate historical patterns | Watch for macroeconomic shifts that alter buying behavior | When significant external changes occur, consider: Creating a "pre/post" analysis to compare attribution before and after | Temporarily applying more weight to recent data vs. historical trends | Resetting baseline metrics if market conditions fundamentally change | Example: "After competitor X shut down, our inbound demo requests jumped 40%. We created a separate attribution model for this unusual period."

sections.warningSignsTitle: Warning Signs That Require Immediate Action

warningSignsList.title: Red Flags for Your Attribution Project

items.title: Data compliance drops
items.description: Data entry compliance drops below 70%

items.title: Meeting attendance declines
items.description: Sales stops attending weekly alignment meetings

items.title: Executive confusion
items.description: Attribution becomes too complex for executives to understand

items.title: Defensive marketing
items.description: Marketing gets defensive about underperforming channels

items.title: Blame reemergence
items.description: Old blame patterns reemerge in pipeline discussions

sections.warningSignsConclusion: When these appear, simplify your approach and reinforce executive support.
sections.pitfallsTitle: Lessons From the Field: Common Pitfalls
sections.pitfallsIntro: Real-world lessons from other CMOs who've been through this:

items.title: Overpromising timeline
items.description: Claiming you'll have perfect attribution in 90 days (it takes 6-12 months)

items.title: Model complexity
items.description: Rolling out algorithmic attribution before basic tracking works

items.title: Blind spots
items.description: Forgetting to track phone calls, chat, or direct outreach

items.title: Tool obsession
items.description: Buying expensive software before fixing process issues

items.title: Missing the people factor
items.description: Creating a great model that no one actually uses

items.title: Data perfectionism
items.description: Trying to fix 10 years of bad CRM data instead of moving forward

items.title: Vanity metrics
items.description: Reporting on activities (clicks, views) instead of outcomes (pipeline, revenue)

items.title: Avoiding bad news
items.description: Not shutting down ineffective channels even when data shows poor performance

items.title: Skipping validation
items.description: Not regularly checking if your attribution is actually accurate

items.title: Forgetting context
items.description: Not considering market changes, sales team changes, or product updates that affect results

sections.conclusionDescription: Your job isn't to implement a perfect attribution model. It's to build organizational credibility for marketing's revenue contribution.

items.title: Sales requesting help
items.description: Sales asking for marketing's help to close deals

items.title: CFO approving budget
items.description: CFO approving marketing budget increases with confidence

items.title: CEO recognition
items.description: CEO referencing marketing's pipeline impact in board meetings

items.title: Clear understanding
items.description: Clear understanding of which marketing activities drive revenue

items.title: Data-backed decisions
items.description: Data-backed decisions replacing opinion-based arguments

sections.conclusionParagraph: The path there isn't just technical - it's organizational. Fix the human elements first, keep the metrics simple, and focus on rebuilding trust through consistent results. This isn't a 90-day fix. It's a fundamental reset of how your company views marketing - from cost center to growth driver. Be patient, be persistent, and solve the human problems before the technical ones.
